title-group.article-title: First Rib Fractures in Abused Infants
title-group.subtitle: A Report of Three Cases

article-meta.aff: 1University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: John D. Melville, 315 N. San Saba Ste 201, San Antonio, TX 78207, USA Email: Melville@uthscsa.edu

abstract.p: The authors describe 4 first rib fractures in 3 infants, highlighting the difficulty in detecting first rib fractures on skeletal survey. All 4 fractures were the result of physical abuse. A literature search does not find a case of first rib fracture in a healthy infant that is not the result of child abuse. The diagnosis of first rib fracture in an infant should prompt a thorough medical and social evaluation for child abuse.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rib fractures in infants aged 1 year and younger are highly specific for child abuse.1 We describe 3 cases of rib fractures in an unusual location: the anterior first rib. We suggest that, compared with other rib fractures, first rib fractures in infants are particularly specific for child abuse.

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: A 4-month-old male infant presented to a children’s hospital emergency department (ED) with a complaint of apnea and turning blue in the presence of both parents. The parents reported no history of trauma. He had numerous petechiae on his face and neck with an otherwise normal physical examination. The patient was a former 34-week premature infant who had previously had a normal pyloric ultrasound for complaints of fussiness and difficulty feeding.

A skeletal survey was interpreted by a pediatric radiologist as showing no fracture (see Figure 1). Ophthalmologic examination was unremarkable. A repeat skeletal survey 12 days following the initial visit was again interpreted by a different pediatric radiologist as showing no fracture (see Figure 2).

caption.p: Case 1 chest x-ray from the time of initial presentation
Case 1 follow-up chest x-ray 12 days following initial presentation

sec.p: Nineteen days after the first visit to the ED, the patient presented to another ED after another episode of facial petechiae was noted by the parents. Examination at that time revealed only otitis media; no petechiae were noted. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest revealed anterior fractures of the left first and second ribs and a lateral fracture of the left fifth rib (see Figure 3). All fractures showed callus and were estimated by a coauthor (EAC) to be between 3 and 4 weeks old. Retrospective review of the first skeletal survey by the same author revealed a lucency of the first rib. A review of the second skeletal survey revealed callus of the first and fifth ribs.

caption.p: Case 1 CT angiogram 19 days following initial presentation

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: A 6-month-old male presented to a children’s ED with his mother, who reported finding the child 15 hours previously on his abdomen with his arm between the slats of his crib. She reported gently removing the arm from between the crib slats. Subsequently, the child refused to use the arm. The child had a linear bruise on his right cheek for which no history was given. Radiographs revealed an acute fracture of the radius and ulna (see Figure 4). Multiple abnormalities were noted on the skeletal survey, including callus of the left first rib, scalloping of both proximal anterior tibias, and a possible buckle fracture of the left tibia. A radionuclide bone scan showed an area of increased uptake over the left first rib, but the remaining concerning areas showed no increased uptake (see Figure 5).

sec.title: Case 3
sec.p: An 11-month-old male presented to the ED with a 2-day history of right leg swelling and severe pain but no history of trauma. Hip films revealed a partially displaced right intratrochanteric fracture (see Figure 6). Skeletal survey revealed bilateral healing clavicular fractures and healing fractures of the right anterior first and seventh ribs.

A second reading of the skeletal survey revealed additional healing fractures of the anterior left first and sixth ribs and a compression fracture of the second thoracic vertebra. A follow-up skeletal survey performed 14 days later revealed a fracture of the right anterior sixth rib. All fractures were judged to be of similar ages.

All 3 cases were investigated by Child Protective Services and law enforcement agencies in consultation with the Division of Child Abuse Pediatrics (including authors JDM and JLL). Child abuse was concluded to be the most likely cause of each injury.

Bone fragility syndromes can present with multiple fractures due to trivial trauma. As documented in Table 1, none of the children demonstrated significant clinical characteristics for osteogenesis imperfecta by history or physical examination. Additionally, no patient demonstrated radiographic or laboratory evidence of osteopenia, vitamin C deficiency, rickets, lytic bone lesions, copper deficiency, Menkes syndrome, or congenital syphilis.

caption.p: Selected Labs and Clinical Findings in 3 Cases

tr.td: Family history of frequent fractures or bone fragility

fn.label: a
fn.p: Value obtained at second visit, 18 days after initial presentation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our series suggests that first rib fractures are difficult to diagnose on skeletal survey even when performed at a children’s hospital and reviewed by a pediatric radiologist. We noted the following in our 3 cases:

list-item.p: The first rib fracture was missed on 2 skeletal surveys 12 days apart. The injury was only discovered after the child underwent a CT scan at another ED.
Suspected “callus” was noted on the first rib by the original clinical team. A radionuclide scan confirmed the finding.
A right first rib fracture was noted by the original pediatric radiologist. The left first rib fracture was noted on a later review by a different pediatric radiologist.

sec.p: In none of our cases was every first rib fracture confidently identified by the primary interpreting radiologist. The difficulty is primarily due to the concentration of overlapping structures in the area, including the scapula, clavicle, second rib, and sometimes, depending on the positioning of the patient, the first rib itself.

Our literature review suggests that first rib fractures in infants, while rare, are particularly specific for child abuse. Strouse and Owings2 reported a series of 5 first rib fractures collected over a period of 12 years. Excluding a child who had osteogenesis imperfecta and innumerable other rib fractures, all the children in Strouse and Owings’s series were abused as evidenced by findings including injuries of multiple ages, other rib fractures, bite marks to cheek and ear, retinal hemorrhage, and one abuser who gave a history of shaking and impact to the head. Kleinman3 presents 2 additional radiographs of first rib fractures attributed to abuse.

Case reports in adults and children beyond infancy document first rib fractures due to multiple mechanisms. Fractures after motor vehicle accidents are reported both with and without restraints.4,5 Sports injuries include football,6 baseball,7 tennis,8 and weightlifting.9-11

Others writers describe first rib fractures in patients who cannot recall traumatic injury. An 8-year-old child heard a “pop” and felt a sharp pain in his neck while sitting in class.12 He subsequently presented with torticollis and a first rib fracture. An 11-year-old girl reportedly had serial fractures of left acromion, clavicle, and lateral first rib attributed to a nervous tic.13 The authors specifically considered and excluded child abuse, and the fractures did not recur after the tics resolved with counseling. A 37-year-old male had bilateral first rib fractures attributed to tardive dystonia.14

Strouse and Owings propose 3 possible mechanisms for first rib fracture in infants: (a) impulsive force (ie, direct impact), (b) compressive force, and/or (c) abusive head trauma. We have attempted to apply these mechanisms to our cases as follows.

sec.title: Impulsive Force
sec.p: Strouse and Owings suggested that impact would be unlikely to fracture the first rib without injury to the scapula or clavicle. Case 3 in our series had bilateral clavicle and first rib fractures that they suggest would indicate direct trauma. However, numerous case reports of older children and adults describe first rib fractures without clavicle or scapula injury. Examples include a 12-year-old pedestrian hit by a vehicle,15 a 23-year-old ejected from a motorbike,16 and an 18-year-old football player who was struck in the scapula.17 In these instances, significant inertial force may have accompanied the direct trauma.

sec.title: Compression
sec.p: Compression is the most common mechanism for rib fractures in infants.3 Three cases in older patients support compression as a cause of first rib fracture: a 10-year-old run over by a tractor,18 a 3-year-old who fell off and was run over by a tractor,4 and a 32-year-old crushed between a forklift and a crate.19

Case 1 in this report presented with extensive facial petechiae. Petechiae of the head and neck have been reported in injuries involving infants “wedged” between furniture such that the thorax could not expand20 or compression of the thorax.21 No history was given to account for the first rib fracture in case 1, but given the presence of 2 additional lateral rib fractures, compression of the left hemithorax would account for the location of the rib fractures in this infant.

sec.title: Abusive Head Trauma
sec.p: The flailing limbs and neck of a shaken infant could fracture the first rib by indirect forces transmitted through the muscles of the shoulder girdle. Reported cases in older patients due to transmitted forces include a 15-year-old swinging a baseball bat,7 a 16-year-old making a tennis serve,8 and a 17-year-old who felt a sudden pull on his arm while surfing.22 The abuser of a patient in one case series of first rib fractures2 gave a history of “shaking and slamming the child down.”

Sudden tension on the arm could explain arm fractures and ipsilateral rib fracture in case 2. However, the rib fracture was clearly healing and the extremity fractures were not. This suggests that the first rib fracture in that case was the result of a separate trauma for which we received no history.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We present 3 cases of physically abused infants with fractures of the first rib. Even though the precise mechanisms of this injury may presently elude us, its striking association with child abuse does not. We are unaware of a single case of first rib fracture in an otherwise healthy infant attributed to a cause other than child abuse. Thus, in the absence of an identified bone disease, identification of first rib fracture in an infant should trigger a diligent medical and social evaluation for possible child abuse.

Our cases illustrate that first rib fractures are easily missed on skeletal surveys. When reviewing radiographs for evidence of abusive injury, clinicians should carefully examine the first rib and have a low threshold for obtaining computed tomography of the chest in infants at risk for this injury.
